revisions.rev:
{{Infobox U.S. County| county = Geauga County | state = Ohio | seal = | founded = March 1, 1806<ref>{{cite web|url = http://development.ohio.gov/research/files/s0/Geauga.pdf |title = Ohio County Profiles: Geauga County |accessdate = 2011-08-20 |publisher = Ohio Department of Development | format = PDF}}</ref> | seat wl = Chardon | largest city = Chardon | area_total_sq_mi = 408 | area_total_km2 = 1057 | area_land_sq_mi = 404 | area_land_km2 = 1045 | area_water_sq_mi = 5 | area_water_km2 = 12 | area percentage = 1.13% | census yr = 2010 | pop = 93,389 | density_sq_mi = 231 | density_km2 = 89 | time zone = Eastern | UTC offset = -5 | DST offset= -4 | web = www.co.geauga.oh.us | named for = a [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] word for "[[raccoon]]" |}}
'''Geauga County''' ({{IPAc-en|icon|dÊ|iË|Ë|ÉË|É¡|É}} {{Respell|jee|AH|gÉ}}) is a [[County (US)|county]] located in the [[U.S. state|state]] of [[Ohio]], [[United States]]. As of the [[United States Census 2010|2010 census]], the population was 93,389.<ref>{{cite web |url=factfinder2.census.gov |title=American FactFinder 2 |publisher=U.S. Census Bureau |year=2010 |accessdate=August 20, 2011}}</ref> It is [[List of Ohio county name etymologies|named]] for a [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] word meaning "[[raccoon]]".<ref>{{cite book |title=Pioneer and General History of Geauga County: With Sketches of Some of the Pioneers and Prominent Men |author=Historical Society of Geauga County, O. |coauthors= |year=1880 |publisher=Historical Society of Geauga County |series= |location= |isbn= |page=24 |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=Eu0uAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA24#v=onepage&q&f=false }}</ref><!--in which Native American language?--><!-- Sources don't say --> The [[county seat]] is [[Chardon, Ohio|Chardon]].{{GR|6}} In 2008, Forbes Magazine ranked Geauga County as the fourth best place in America to raise a family.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.forbes.com/home/2008/06/27/schools-places-family-forbeslife-cz_zg_0630realestate.html | work=Forbes | title=America's Best Places To Raise A Family | date=June 30, 2008}}</ref>
Geauga County is part of the [[Cleveland, Ohio|Cleveland]]–[[Elyria, Ohio|Elyria]]–[[Mentor, Ohio|Mentor]] [[Greater Cleveland|Metropolitan Statistical Area]].
==History== Geauga County was founded on March 1, 1806 as the second county in the [[Connecticut Western Reserve]], originating from [[Trumbull County, Ohio]]. Geauga County is named after the [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] word "Sheauga" meaning "[[raccoon]]. In 1808, the size of Geauga County was reduced by the creation of [[Ashtabula County, Ohio|Ashtabula County]] and [[Cuyahoga County, Ohio|Cuyahoga County]].
The present-day boundaries were established in 1840 following the creation of [[Lake County, Ohio|Lake County]]. A disagreement about the location of the county seat began in 1808 when commissioners from [[Trumbull County, Ohio|Trumbull County]] began the process of identifying the seat of justice.<ref>{{cite book|last=Stith|first=B.A.|title=Lake County, Ohio: 150 Years of Tradition|year=1989|publisher=Windsor Publications|location=Northridge, CA}}</ref> Residents in the northern townships wanted the seat in Champion, renamed [[Painesville, Ohio]] in 1832.<ref name=stith>{{cite web|last=Stith|first=B.A.|title=A Vision Divided|url=http://www.case.edu/artsci/wrss/documents/Stith_000.pdf|publisher=Case Western Reserve University|accessdate=August 21, 2011}}</ref> Residents in southern townships desired a centrally-located county seat and took advantage of a tract of land donated by Peter Chardon Brooks called [[Chardon, Ohio]]. Despite Chardon being selected in 1809, the argument was never really settled. Over the next two decades, population growth in the seven northern townships exceeded the remaining sixteen southern townships, further fueling the disagreement. On January 21, 1840, a petition to create Lake County from seven townships in northern Geauga County and [[Willoughby, Ohio|Willoughby Township]] from [[Cuyahoga County]] were presented to the Ohio House of Representatives.<ref name=stith/> [[Seabury Ford]] presented petitions against its creation. Lake County was established in March 1840 by the Ohio state legislature. As the newly-formed Lake County did not have sufficient territory to meet the requirements for a county, the northern border included submerged land beneath the waters of [[Lake Erie]].
The first settlement in Geauga, was at [[Burton, Ohio]] in the year 1798, when three families settled there from [[Connecticut]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Howe|first=Henry|title=Historical Collections of Ohio|year=1852|publisher=Bradley & Anthony|location=Cincinnati, Ohio|pages=187â190}}</ref>
==Geography== According to the [[United States Census Bureau|U.S. Census Bureau]], the county has a total area of {{convert|408|sqmi|1}}.{{convert|404|sqmi|1}} is land and {{convert|5|sqmi|1}} (1.13%) is water.
Geauga County receives the most precipitation of any county in northern Ohio, with most of the county receiving over 42 inches annually in an average year, and some parts exceeding 44 inches.<ref>[http://www.ocs.orst.edu/pub/maps/Precipitation/Total/States/OH/oh.gif "Average Annual Preciptation: Ohio", Map, Published by Oregon State University, Data from 1961-1990.]</ref>
===Drainage System=== The [[geography]] of Geauga County was radically changed by [[Illinoian glaciation|Illinoian]] and [[Wisconsinan glaciation]], which is evident in the deranged [[Drainage system (geomorphology)|drainage system]], landscape change, and [[Till|glacial till]]. The [[headwater]]s of three [[river|watercourses]] in the [[Lake Erie]] [[drainage basin|basin]] are located in Geauga County. These include the [[Cuyahoga River]], [[Chagrin River]], and [[Grand River (Ohio)|Grand River]]. Portions of all three are designated [http://www.dnr.state.oh.us/tabid/985/Default.aspx Ohio Scenic Rivers].<ref>{{cite web|title=Scenic Rivers|url=http://www.dnr.state.oh.us/tabid/985/Default.aspx|work=Ohio Scenic Rivers Program|publisher=Ohio Dept of Natural Resources (ODNR)|accessdate=August 28, 2011}}</ref>
Point sources of the east branch of the [[Cuyahoga River]] are located in [[Hambden Township, Geauga County, Ohio|Hambden Township]], [[Claridon Township, Geauga County, Ohio|Claridon Township]], and [[Burton Township, Geauga County, Ohio|Burton Township]],.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cuyahoga River|url=http://ech.case.edu/ech-cgi/article.pl?id=CR9|work=The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History|publisher=Case Western Reserve University|accessdate=August 28, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=East Branch Cuyahoga River (ID:1039937)|url=http://geonames.usgs.gov/pls/gnispublic/f?p=gnispq:3:::NO::P3_FID:1039938|work=Geographic Names Information System (GNIS)|publisher=U.S. Geological Survey|accessdate=August 28, 2011}}</ref> The point source of the west branch of the Cuyahoga River is near the intersection of Pond and Rapids Roads in [[Burton Township, Geauga County, Ohio|Burton Township]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Upper Cuyahoga State Scenic River|url=http://www.dnr.state.oh.us/tabid/984/Default.aspx|work=Ohio State Scenic Rivers|publisher=ODNR|accessdate=August 28, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Cuyahoga River (ID:1072205)|url=http://geonames.usgs.gov/pls/gnispublic/f?p=gnispq:3:::NO::P3_FID:1072205|work=Geographic Names Information System (GNIS)|publisher=U.S. Geological Survey|accessdate=August 28, 2011}}</ref>
The point sources of the east branch of the [[Chagrin River]] are at Bass Lake in [[Munson Township, Geauga County, Ohio|Munson Township]] and the southwest corner of [[Chardon, Ohio|the City of Chardon]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Chagrin River|url=http://ech.case.edu/ech-cgi/article.pl?id=CR1|work=The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History|publisher=Case Western Reserve University|accessdate=August 28, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=East Branch Chagrin River (ID:1039937)|url=http://geonames.usgs.gov/pls/gnispublic/f?p=gnispq:3:::NO::P3_FID:1039937|work=Geographic Names Information System (GNIS)|publisher=U.S. Geological Survey|accessdate=August 28, 2011}}</ref> McFarland Creek in [[Bainbridge Township, Geauga County, Ohio|Bainbridge Township]], sometimes referred to as Chagrin Falls because of the postal zip code, is a tributary of the [[Aurora, Ohio|Aurora]] branch of the [[Chagrin River]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Aurora Branch Chagrin River (ID:1066554)|url=http://geonames.usgs.gov/pls/gnispublic/f?p=gnispq:3:::NO::P3_FID:1066554|work=Geographic Names Information System|publisher=U.S. Geological Survey|accessdate=August 28, 2011}}</ref>
Point sources of the [[Grand River (Ohio)|Grand River]] are located in [[Parkman Township, Geauga County, Ohio|Parkman Township]], [[Troy Township, Geauga County, Ohio|Troy Township]], and Swine Creek in [[Middlefield Township, Geauga County, Ohio|Middlefield Township]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Grand State Wild and Scenic River|url=http://www.dnr.state.oh.us/tabid/1859/Default.aspx|work=Ohio State Scenic Rivers|publisher=ODNR|accessdate=August 28, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Grand River (ID:1066727)|url=http://geonames.usgs.gov/pls/gnispublic/f?p=154:3:::NO:3:P3_FID,P3_TITLE:1066727%2CGrand%20River|work=Geographic Names Information System|publisher=U.S. Geological Survey|accessdate=August 28, 2011}}</ref>
While the majority of waterways in Geauga County are part of the [[Lake Erie]] [[drainage basin|watershed]], the Silver Creek in [[Troy Township, Geauga County, Ohio|Troy Township]] is a tributary to the west branch of the [[Mahoning River]], part of the [[Ohio River|Ohio River watershed]], the largest tributary to the [[Mississippi River]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Silver Creek (ID: 1046276)|url=http://geonames.usgs.gov/pls/gnispublic/f?p=154:3:::NO:3:P3_FID,P3_TITLE:1046276%2CSilver%20Creek|work=Geographic Names Information System|publisher=U.S. Geological Survey|accessdate=August 28, 2011}}</ref> There is another Silver Creek in Geauga County located in [[Russell Township, Geauga County, Ohio|Russell Township]], which is a tributary to the east branch of the [[Chagrin River]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Silver Creek (ID: 1046273)|url=http://geonames.usgs.gov/pls/gnispublic/f?p=154:3:::NO:3:P3_FID,P3_TITLE:1046273%2CSilver%20Creek|work=Geographic Names Information System|publisher=U.S. Geological Survey|accessdate=August 28, 2011}}</ref>
===Adjacent counties=== *[[Lake County, Ohio|Lake County]] (north) *[[Ashtabula County, Ohio|Ashtabula County]] (northeast) *[[Trumbull County, Ohio|Trumbull County]] (southeast) *[[Portage County, Ohio|Portage County]] (south) *[[Cuyahoga County, Ohio|Cuyahoga County]] (west) *[[Summit County, Ohio|Summit County]] (southwest corner)
==Demographics==
{{USCensusPop |1810=2917 |1820=7791 |1830=15813 |1840=16297 |1850=17827 |1860=15817 |1870=14190 |1880=14251 |1890=13489 |1900=14744 |1910=14670 |1920=15036 |1930=15414 |1940=19430 |1950=26646 |1960=47573 |1970=62977 |1980=74474 |1990=81129 |2000=90895 |2010=93389 }}
As of the [[census]]of 2010,<ref>{{cite web|title=American Factfinder|url=http://factfinder2.census.gov/faces/tableservices/jsf/pages/productview.xhtml?pid=DEC_10_DP_DPDP1&prodType=table|work=Geauga County, Ohio|publisher=U.S. Census Bureau|accessdate=2011-09-10}}</ref> there were 93,389 people, 34,264 households, and 25,654 families residing in the county. The [[population density]] was 231.1 people per square mile (89.3/kmÂ²). There were 34,264 occupied housing units at an average density of 84.8 per square mile (32.8/kmÂ²). The racial makeup of the county was 96.9% [[Race (United States Census)|White]], 1.3% [[Race (United States Census)|Black]] or [[Race (United States Census)|African American]], 0.1% [[Race (United States Census)|Native American]], 0.6% [[Race (United States Census)|Asian]], 0.001% [[Race (United States Census)|Pacific Islander]], 0.3% from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 0.8% from two or more races.
There were 34,264 households out of which 31.6% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 63.8% were [[Marriage|married couples]] living together, 7.70% had a female householder with no husband present, 3.50% had a male householder with no wife present, and 25.10% were non-families. 25.10% of all households were made up of individuals and 9.50% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.70 and the average family size was 3.16.
In the county the population was spread out with 26.0% under the age of 18, 6.60% from 18 to 24, 20.1% from 25 to 44, 31.8% from 45 to 64, and 15.50% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 43.3 years. For every 100 females there were 96.85 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 93.72 males.
As of the [[census]]{{GR|2}} of 2000, 0.59% of the population were [[Race (United States Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Race (United States Census)|Latino]] of any race. 21.7% were of [[German people|German]], 11.0% [[Italian people|Italian]], 10.9% [[Irish people|Irish]], 10.1% [[English people|English]], 6.3% [[Polish people|Polish]] and 6.2% [[United States|American]] ancestry according to [[Census 2000]]. 89.4% spoke [[English language|English]], 5.1% [[German language|German]], 1.5% [[Pennsylvania German language|Pennsylvania Dutch]] and 1.0% [[Spanish language|Spanish]] as their first language.
As of the [[census]]{{GR|2}} of 2000, the median income for a household in the county was $60,200, and the median income for a family was $67,427. Males had a median income of $48,443 versus $30,567 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the county was $27,944. About 2.80% of families and 4.60% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 6.10% of those under age 18 and 5.10% of those age 65 or over. The median household income and per capita income were [[Highest-income counties in the United States|the second highest among Ohio counties after Delaware, and 74th and 79th in the country, respectively.]]

An official [http://www.co.geauga.oh.us/Portals/0/resources/County%20Documents/planning%20commission/Geauga_County_Transportation_2005-10-31.pdf Geauga County Road Map]
===Public Transportation=== The rural nature of Geauga County limits the feasibility of a fixed-route transit system. Instead, [[Geauga County Transit]] offers a demand-responsive door-to-door transit system within the County with some out-of-county service. As of 2011, one-way fares for door-to-door service were $6.00, with 50% discounts for the elderly, disabled, or children 6-years to 17-years old. Children 5-years and younger are free. Out-of-county fares are two times the posted in-county fares. Service is provided 6:00 AM to 9:00 PM Monday through Friday. Reservations are suggested with at least three days notice, but can be made up to one week in advance. [http://www.geaugatransit.org/ Geauga County Transit]
===Airports=== Geauga County is home to one [[List of airports in Ohio|public airport]] located at 15421 Old State Road, [[Middlefield, Ohio]] 44062. Contact Airport Authority: (440) 632-1884. [http://www.co.geauga.oh.us/Portals/0/resources/County%20Documents/planning%20commission/Regional_Transportation_11x17.pdf Greater Geauga County Highway Access & Airport Service Map]. The Geauga County Airport call sign is 7G8. It is home to [http://5.eaachapter.org/ Experimental Aircraft Association Chapter 5].
The Geauga County Airport sits on 41-acres purchased by the Middlefield Chamber of Commerce and donated to Geauga County. Ground was broken August 31, 1967 and it was officially opened September 29, 1968. The airport has one 3500' long by 65' wide runway. Runway numbers are 11 on the west end and 29 on the east end. There are two T-hangars, one private hangar, two community hangars, a pilot lounge and restroom facility. [http://www.co.geauga.oh.us/Departments/Airport/Main.aspx The official airport Web site] and [http://www.airnav.com/airport/7G8 Airnav Statistics Web site].
== Education == ===Public School Districts=== Geauga County is home to seven public school districts as illustrated in [[List_of_school_districts_in_Ohio#G|this list of school districts in Ohio]].
The [http://geaugaesc.org Geauga County Educational Service Center] provides collaborative programs and services for the seven local school districts in Geauga County, leveraging resources to reduce overall costs to each district. The ESC has formed a P-16 bridge initiative whose ''mission is to create workforce readiness in our youth and adults through substantive partnerships between educators, businesses, community organizations, parents focusing on important transitions experienced at each level. Geauga County P-16 will develop a sustainable process and program to insure its continued success''.<ref>{{cite web|title=P-16 Bridge|url=http://geaugaesc.org/modules/cms/pages.phtml?pageid=205491&sessionid=e4e08f523c7ad31e90a2f532db5ee9dc|work=Geauga ESC|publisher=Geauga ESC|accessdate=August 20, 2011}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" ! District ! Location ! Communities served |- | [http://www.berkshireschools.org/ Berkshire Local School District] | [[Burton, Ohio]] | Burton Township, Burton Village, most of Claridon Township, Troy Township, Welshfield |- | [http://www.cardinal.k12.oh.us/ Cardinal Local School District] | [[Middlefield, Ohio]] | Huntsburg Township, Middlefield Township, Middlefield Village, Parkman Township, small part of Mespotamia (Trumbull County) |- | [http://www.chardon.k12.oh.us/ Chardon Local School District] | [[Chardon, Ohio]] | Aquilla Village, Chardon City, Chardon Township, part of Claridon Township, Hambden Township, most of Munson Township, very small part of Concord Township (Lake County) |- | [http://www.kenston.k12.oh.us/ Kenston Local School District] | [[Bainbridge Township, Geauga County, Ohio|Bainbridge Township, Ohio]] | Auburn Township, most of Bainbridge Township |- | [http://www.ledgemont.k12.oh.us/ Ledgemont Local School District] | [[Thompson Township, Geauga County, Ohio|Thompson, Ohio]] | Montville Township, Thompson Township, small part Huntsburg Township |- | [http://www.newburyschools.org/ Newbury Local School District] | [[Newbury Township, Geauga County, Ohio|Newbury, Ohio]] | Newbury Township |- | [http://www.westgeauga.k12.oh.us/ West Geauga County Local School District] | [[Chester Township, Geauga County, Ohio|Chester Township, Ohio]] | Chester Township, Chesterland, small part of Hunting Valley, part of Munson Township, unincorporated part of Russell Township |} [[File:Geauga County school districts overlay (revised).png|thumb| Map of school districts in Geauga County with township boundaries superimposed]] In addition, there are five neighboring public school districts that serve portions of Geauga County residents.
{| class="wikitable" ! District ! Location ! Communities served in Geauga County |- | [http://www.chagrinschools.org Chagrin Falls Exempted Village School District] | [[Chagrin Falls, Ohio]] and [[South Russell, Ohio]] | South Russell Village; small parts of Bainbridge and Russell Townships |- | [http://www.kirtlandschools.org/ Kirtland Local School District] | [[Kirtland, Ohio]] | small part of Chardon Township |- | [http://www.madison-lake.k12.oh.us/ Madison Local School District] | [[Madison, Ohio]] | small part of Thompson Township |- | [http://mentorschools.net Mentor Exempted Village School District] | [[Mentor, Ohio]] | small part of Chardon Township |- | [http://riverside.k12.oh.us/ Riverside Local School District] | [[Painesville, Ohio]] | small part of Chardon Township |}
===Joint Vocational School District=== Taxpayers in six of the seven school districts in Geauga County support a Joint Vocational School District (JVSD) at the [http://www.auburncc.org/ Auburn Career Center] in [[Concord Township, Lake County, Ohio|Concord Township, Ohio]]. The career center offers a variety of programs in health, education, and hands-on technology.
===Private and Parochial Schools=== Geauga County is home to eight private, parochial, and/or specialized schools.
{| class="wikitable" ! District ! Location ! Communities served |- | [http://agapeca.com/ Agape Christian Academy] | [[Burton Township, Ohio]] and [[Troy Township, Geauga County, Ohio|Troy Township, Ohio]] | Accepts applications prior to the start of each school year |- | [http://www.hawken.edu/ Hawken School] | [[Gates Mills, Ohio]] | College preparatory day school: online application, site visit and testing |- | [http://hershey-montessori.org/ Hershey Montessori Farm School] | [[Huntsburg Township, Geauga County, Ohio|Huntsburg Township, Ohio]] | parent-owned, and chartered by [[Ohio Department of Education]]: application deadline January each year |- | [http://ndcl.org/ Notre Dame-Cathedral Latin] | [[Munson Township, Geauga County, Ohio|Munson Township, Ohio]] | Roman Catholic Diocese of Cleveland: open to 8th grade students who have attended a Catholic elementary school and others who have not |- | [http://www.bainbridgemontessori.org/ Solon/Bainbridge Montessori School of Languages] | [[Bainbridge Township, Geauga County, Ohio|Bainbridge Township, Ohio]] | nonsectarian [[Montessori School]]: quarterly enrollment periods |- | [http://www.csnmail.net/~sas/ Saint Anselm School] | [[Chester Township, Geauga County, Ohio|Chester Township, Ohio]] | Roman Catholic Diocese of Cleveland K - 8th grade; preschool |- | [http://www.sthelen.com/School/ Saint Helen's School] | [[Newbury Township, Geauga County, Ohio|Newbury, Ohio]] | Roman Catholic Diocese of Cleveland K - 8th grade; parishioners and non-parishioners |- | [http://www.stmaryschoolchardon.org/ Saint Mary's School] | [[Chardon, Ohio]] | Roman Catholic Diocese of Cleveland preschool - 8th grade; parishioners and non-parishioners |}
===Higher education=== Geauga County is home to one institution of higher learning:
* [http://www.geauga.kent.edu/ Kent State University - Geauga] is located in [[Burton, Ohio]]. KSU - Geauga is one of [[Kent State University#Regional campuses|seven regional campuses]] of [[Kent State University]]. The 87-acre Burton Township campus was established as an academic center in 1964 and became a regional campus in 1976. As of 2011, more than 2,000 full and part-time students are enrolled. There is no student housing on the Geauga campus. KSU -Geauga offers a variety of academic programs, including [[certificate program]]s, [[Associate's degree]], and [[Bachelor's degree]] in business, education, general studies, nursing, science, and technology.

== Notable People == *[[Peter Hitchcock]] (1781â1853) lawyer, soldier, legislator, judge, [[Ohio House of Representatives]] 1810 - 1811, [[Ohio Senate]] 1812 - 1815, President of the Ohio Senate 1815, [http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=H000647 15th US Congress (March 4, 1817-March 3, 1819)], [[Ohio Supreme Court|Supreme Court of Ohio]] as [[List of Justices of the Ohio Supreme Court|Justice of the Ohio Supreme Court]] 1821 - 1828, [[Chief Justice of the Ohio Supreme Court|Chief Judge of the Ohio Supreme Court]] 1829 - 1833, [[List of Justices of the Ohio Supreme Court|Justice of the Ohio Supreme Court]] 1835 - 1842, [[List of Justices of the Ohio Supreme Court|Justice of the Ohio Supreme Court]] 1845 - 1852 *[[Seabury Ford]] (1801â1855) nephew of [[Peter Hitchcock]], lawyer, [[List of Governors of Ohio|20th Governor of Ohio]] 1849 - 1850 *[[Albert G. Riddle|Albert Gallatin Riddle]] (1816â1902) lawyer, educator, 8th prosecuting attorney for Geauga County 1842 - 1848, [[Ohio House of Representatives]] 1848 - 1850, [http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=R000238 Thirty-seventh Congress (March 4, 1861-March 3, 1863)], assisted in prosecution of [[John Surratt]] - an accomplice in the assassination of [[Abraham Lincoln]] *[[Mortimer Dormer Leggett|General Mortimer Leggett]] (1821â1896) [[American Civil War|Civil War]] general, commander of Volunteer Army of Ohio *[[Seth Ledyard Phelps]] (1824â1885) US Navy 1841 - 1875, [[Lieutenant Commander]] during [[American Civil War]], [[List_of_mayors_of_Washington,_D.C.#Presidents_of_the_Board_of_Commissioners_(1874â1975)|President of the District of Columbia Board of Commissioners]] 1878â1879 * [[Halbert E. Paine|Halbert Eleazer Paine]] (1826â1905) lawyer, [[Brigadier general (United States)|brigadier general]] and [[Major general (United States)|major general]] in [[American Civil War]], [http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=P000028 Thirty-ninth, Fortieth, and Forty-first Congresses (March 4, 1865-March 3, 1871)], [[List of people who have headed the United States Patent Office|US Commissioner of Patents]] 1879 - 1881 * Delos W. Canfield (1828â1900 ) farmer, attorney, real estate, 13th prosecuting attorney of Geauga County 1862â1866; Ohio House of Representatives 1868-69;<ref name=Annals>{{cite book|last=Scobey|first=FE and Doty, EW.|title=Biographical Annals of Ohio: A handbook of the government and institutions o the State of Ohio|year=1904|publisher=The Springfield Publishing Company|location=Springfield, Ohio|pages=262|url=http://www.archive.org/details/biographicalann01unkngoog}}</ref> Common Pleas Judges of the Ninth District 1875-1877, 1885-1900 (his death) <ref name=Annals/> *[[Charles Martin Hall]], inventor of modern aluminum production process *[[Matt Hutter]], [[NASCAR]] driver
